title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Understand ORM translation!

1. Create a 'Book' class:
   - int Id
   - string Title
   - string Author
   - decimal Price
   - int Year

2. Create sample LINQ queries and show what SQL they would generate:

   Query 1: Find all books by \"Orwell\"
   - C# LINQ: books.Where(b => b.Author == \"Orwell\")
   - Print equivalent SQL

   Query 2: Find books over $20, sorted by price
   - C# LINQ: books.Where(b => b.Price > 20).OrderBy(b => b.Price)
   - Print equivalent SQL

   Query 3: Get titles of books from 2020+
   - C# LINQ: books.Where(b => b.Year >= 2020).Select(b => b.Title)
   - Print equivalent SQL

3. Show benefits of ORM:
   - Print why type safety matters
   - Print why LINQ is better than SQL strings
   - Print relationship navigation benefit

hints.text: Show LINQ query, then equivalent SQL. LINQ: .Where(condition).OrderBy(field).Select(field). SQL: SELECT field FROM table WHERE condition ORDER BY field.
Thinking ORM is slower: Yes, hand-optimized SQL CAN be faster. But for 95% of queries, ORM is fast enough! And developer productivity matters more than microseconds.
Using ORM for everything: Complex reports with 10 joins? Sometimes raw SQL is clearer! ORMs excel at CRUD operations. Use SQL for complex analytics.
Not understanding SQL: ORM doesn't mean 'never learn SQL!' You should understand what SQL is generated. Use logging to see queries. Debug performance issues!
Lazy loading traps: ORM can cause N+1 query problem! Loading 100 customers, then customer.Orders for each = 101 queries! Use .Include() to eager load (next lessons).
